results.title: A Good Eye for Story
results.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz
Special thanks to CAAMA Productions
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
results.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.
results.headline_credit_for_label:
filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)

Equipment provided by Panavision Australia

Colour by Matt Fezz
results.description:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River
description_for_label:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River

results.title: The Silenced
results.credit_line:
Julie Gough
Single-channel video, 6:18 mins.
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
results.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough
description_for_label:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania.

Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

In works such as “The Silenced” (2020) Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.”

results.title: Where the Desert Meets the Sea
results.credit_line:
Cinematography by Brad Gibb 
Edited by Ben Lane  
Special thanks to Wayne Miller
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 4:12 min
results.brief_description: Shelley Ware’s film Where the Desert Meets the Sea (2020) tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.
results.description:
Shelley Ware is one of Australia’s most respected female sports presenters. She is a Yankunytjatjara, Wirangu and Kokatha woman, well known for her role on the SBS program Marngrook Footy Show. Currently, Ware hosts the AFL.com web show ‘Colour of Your Jumper’. Ware is also an educator, and her film Where the Desert Meets the Sea tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.

“This is a story of my Country and why the game of AFL and the Koonibba Football Club are so important to me. I share the stories of my people, as a teacher and sports presenter, so that our children, can be what they see.” – Shelley Ware
description_for_label:
Shelley Ware is one of Australia’s most respected female sports presenters. She is a Yankunytjatjara, Wirangu and Kokatha woman, well known for her role on the SBS program Marngrook Footy Show. Ware is also an educator, and her film Where the Desert Meets the Sea tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.

results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.credit_line:
Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung) and Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)

Single-channel video, 7.39 mins

Filmed and edited by Dr Romaine Moreton

Co-directed by Dr Romaine Moreton and Dr Lou Bennett AM

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet

Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM

Arranged by Iain Grandage

Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Engineered by Russell Thomson

ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
“The making of “Jaara Nyilamum” (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within Country, and from this place of rooted calmness, Country reaffirmed our Law is real. “Jaara Nyilamum” became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.” – Dr Lou Bennett AM and Dr Romaine Moreton

Dr Lou Bennett is a performer, songwriter, musical and artistic director, composer, actor, soundscape designer and academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the arts to enhance community health and wellbeing.

Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of storytelling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)

results.title: Catalyst: Fire Storm
results.creator_credit: Andrew Holland, Ian Cuming and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
A scientific investigation into the causes of the catastrophic Canberra bushfires of January 2003 where 474 homes were destroyed and four lives lost. Includes interviews with residents, scientists, environmentalists and fire-fighters.
Episode from the ABC TV series ‘Catalyst’ presented and narrated by Karina Kelly.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Holland, Ian Cuming and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Sept Visions Fugitives
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: Sept Visions Fugitives was produced in China. Cahen creates impressionistic transformations of landscape and people. He writes: “The looking and listening audiences are confronted — in addition to the pure impressions — with basic questions about work (the boy using a traditional device to shake the feathers from the mattress) about freedom, about life in China … and ultimately about life and death: the burial, the bird, the man with a sheaf of straw on his back symbolizing the passage, the beyond ….. I had to struggle to make what I know are stereotyped images my own. The pure impressions and raw filmic material are completely reworked, going much further than the original takes.” Source: Electronic Arts Intermix [www.eai.org]

results.title: After the Tsunami: Schools Helping Schools in Aceh
results.creator_credit: ABC Asia Pacific and Barry Mitchell
results.brief_description: On 26th December 2004, a massive earthquake in the Indian Ocean caused the tsunamis that devastated many nearby coastal areas, with no area more profoundly affected than the province of Aceh in Indonesia. Over 150,000 people were killed, many of them school students, their parents and teachers, and many schools were partly, or completely destroyed. Governments all over the world offered money and aid, but even small organisations can have a big impact. The International Baccalaureate Organisation set up its ‘schools to schools’ program especially to connect schools in tsunami-affected regions with schools in Australia and other countries. This documentary shows how schools in Indonesia have started to pick up the pieces, and how the IBO is helping to rebuild.

results.title: Landline: Stripping the Myth
results.brief_description:
‘Landline’ is the ABC’s national rural issues program.

This episode investigates the conventionally accepted history of the invention and development of the combine harvester. The widely held belief that a young Victorian, Hugo Victor McKay, was the inventor of the world’s first such machine is exposed as a myth.

First broadcast on 13th March, 2005.

results.title: Bush Mechanics: Episode 4: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly, David Batty, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Warlpiri Media and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The ‘Bush Mechanics’ comprise a group of five young Warlpiri men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, the ‘Bush Mechanics’ series follows the men across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits. In Episode 4, these involve covering thousands of kilometres across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: A Dairyland Romance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
Story revolves around the importance of choosing breeding partners that have good breeding themselves and the benefits that this will bring their offspring. It stars two cows with human characteristics (standing on two legs, wearing clothes, speaking english, etc.) being interviewed about their successful partnership together and goes on to give information on correct rearing techniques. Hand-painted animation looks suberb and the deadpan delivery of the main charcaters is very amusing.

Illustrated ‘The End’ and opening titles.
